channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: EU Unveils Regulations Targeting Big Tech
item.description: The walls are closing in This week, the FTC ordered top U.S. tech companies to explain their user data practices, China fined its own tech leaders Alibaba and Tencent over antitrust violations, and the UK proposed fines of up to 10% of global revenue if tech giants don't remove illegal content.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Warren Buffett, David Solomon Urge Congress to Extend PPP for Small Businesses
item.description: PPP has been criticized for fraud and not actually going to small businesses. It's a $525 billion government program intended to help small businesses keep workers on payroll. In an interview with CNBC yesterday morning, legendary investor Warren Buffett urged Congress to pass legislation to help small businesses stay afloat. Help could be on the way if Congress gets the job done.   A real-world example: This summer, American Airlines was able to raise $2.5 billion from selling bonds even as it was bleeding $58 million/day.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Anna Wintour Promoted at Condé Nast, Again
item.description: The backstory: Wintour became U.S. Vogue editor in 1988, then added the "artistic director" title in 2014.   Wintour apologized for her role in sidelining Black creators in June. CEO Roger Lynch plans to lean on 1) digital video and 2) paywalls to reach profitability.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: President-elect Biden Taps Pete Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary
item.description: Buttigieg endorsed Biden and helped him raise money, despite Biden having run an ad mocking Buttigieg's relatively paltry experience.     More broadly, Buttigieg will manage a nearly $90 billion budget, plus oversee the agencies that regulate railroads, trucking, and aviation.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Amazon Owned Zoox Unveils Autonomous Robotaxi
item.description: It’s fast(ish): Topping out at 75 mph, it’s the speediest robotaxi in the industry. But for now, Zoox is 100% focused on people, not packages. “In a nutshell, we want to eventually move people around a city,” CEO Aicha Evans told journalist Kara Swisher in an interview.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Pornhub Bows to Pressure, Deletes Unverified Videos
item.description: Mastercard and Visa, which process payments on the site, launched an investigation.   But that wasn’t enough.   That piece set off a chain of events that have “left the porn industry shaken,” according to Motherboard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Assessing the Fallout from the SolarWinds Hack
item.description: As for the identity of the hackers, multiple outlets say all signs point to a specific group of Russian state-backed hackers called “APT29” or “Cozy Bear.”   The backstory: Hackers infiltrated the IT systems of several federal agencies and top corporations via a product made by software company SolarWinds.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: U.S. Healthcare Workers Receive First Covid Vaccines
item.description: More than 300,000 Americans have died from Covid-19. Three million more doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine will be delivered across the country this week.     Yesterday, NYC’s mayor told the city to prepare for a potential “full shutdown.” The longer process has drawn criticism from some European leaders.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Exxon Mobil Pledges Emission Cuts
item.description: Looking ahead…while fossil fuel companies struggle, a new guard of clean energy giants is beating them to investor dollars and ushering in energy’s “NextEra.”   While some are making efforts, including net-zero emissions targets and diversifying into renewables, “there doesn't seem to be an oil major that's got it all figured out between the pandemic, cloudy demand and price outlooks, and the unknown path through a world getting a bit more serious about climate,” Axios writes. Reduce overall emissions intensity by 15%–20% Halve methane emission intensity Emission “intensity”?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Exxon Mobil Pledges Emission Cuts
item.description: Looking ahead…while fossil fuel companies struggle, a new guard of clean energy giants is beating them to investor dollars and ushering in energy’s “NextEra.”   While some are making efforts, including net-zero emissions targets and diversifying into renewables, “there doesn't seem to be an oil major that's got it all figured out between the pandemic, cloudy demand and price outlooks, and the unknown path through a world getting a bit more serious about climate,” Axios writes. He’s pledged to rejoin the Paris Accord on Day 1, invest $2 trillion in clean energy, and get the U.S. on a path to net-zero carbon emissions “no later than 2050.”
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: U.S. Healthcare Workers Receive First Covid Vaccines
item.description: More than 300,000 Americans have died from Covid-19. Three million more doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine will be delivered across the country this week.     Yesterday, NYC’s mayor told the city to prepare for a potential “full shutdown.” The longer process has drawn criticism from some European leaders.

item.description: Mastercard and Visa, which process payments on the site, launched an investigation.   But that wasn’t enough.   That piece set off a chain of events that have “left the porn industry shaken,” according to Motherboard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Taking a Look at the Fallout from the SolarWinds Hack
item.description: The hack was first identified last week by FireEye, a cybersecurity company that itself was hacked.   As for the identity of the hackers, multiple outlets say all signs point to a specific group of Russian state-backed hackers called “APT29” or “Cozy Bear.”
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Week Ahead: Tesla's Grand Entrance and Another Vaccine
item.description: Everything else: Christopher Nolan's Tenet will be released digitally on Tuesday.    Tesla gets promoted: On Friday, Elon Musk's $578 billion electric automaker will join the S&P 500 index. Friday is National Ugly Sweater Day. A major snowstorm could hit the East Coast mid-week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Kevin From 'The Office' Will Bring in More Than $1 Million on Cameo This Year
item.description: But Galanis thinks President Trump would crush Dobrik if he joined Cameo. Since he charges $195/video, we estimate Baumgartner will have averaged at least 14 videos per day in 2020.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Roblox, Affirm Delay IPOs to Early 2021
item.description: And even companies that make no money are soaring: At least three electric vehicle companies worth more than $2 billion have no revenue. Recent IPO trends may lead them to sell more shares or price them differently. Affirm and Roblox were hoping for valuations as high as $10 billion and $8 billion, respectively.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: George Senate Races Attracting Attention from Corporate America
item.description: the vote is scheduled for Jan. 5, but in-person early voting starts today. Looking ahead... Its online fundraising platform processed nearly $112 million in donations from Nov. 4 to Nov. 23 (the GOP equivalent processed $55.6 million).
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The First Covid-19 Vaccines Are Being Delivered
item.description: Altogether, around 3 million doses will snake their way to 636 distribution centers across the country in the coming days.   The vaccine requires two shots a month apart, so officials are saving the second half of the ~6.4 million doses planned for the first wave to send out in a few weeks.   Supply chain: In 2009, delivery timetables for the swine flu vaccine shifted regularly. It's expected to get approval. The remaining challenges Spoilage: Pfizer's vaccine needs to maintain -94°F, and although the company has equipped shipping containers with dry ice and GPS-enabled temperature sensors, it's expected that some doses won't survive the journey.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.description: But Galanis thinks President Trump would crush Dobrik if he joined Cameo. Since he charges $195/video, we estimate Baumgartner will have averaged at least 14 videos per day in 2020.

item.title: Your Candy Bar Has a Dark Secret
item.description: Originally filed in 2005, the case alleges the companies violated international laws against child slavery." Nestlé and Cargill say they've made efforts to eliminate child labor from supply chains. The chocolate supply chain is riddled with child labor.    That's one of the problems with the cocoa supply chain.   An October report from the Labor Department estimates ~1.6 million children are working on cocoa farms. A decision on the side of Nestlé and Cargill could affect future human rights cases brought under the ATS.    This case could have big implications for corporate liability The case centers on the Alien Tort Statute (ATS), a provision nearly as old as the U.S. that provides a path for foreign nationals to sue over violations of international law or U.S. treaties abroad in American courts.   This wasn't the Court's first dance with ATS.   They won't have to worry...   Ex.: The ATS has been invoked in conversations around corporate liability for supply chains linked to imprisoned Uighur Muslims in China."   While the justices weren't convinced that ATS was the right statute to use in pursuit of this case...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Hyundai Acquires Boston Dynamics and Its Robot Dogs for $1.1 Billion
item.description: Some of the sectors Boston Dynamics’s tech might help with one day: self-driving vehicles, smart factories, and healthcare.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: The Popping IPO Market Could Be “Broken”
item.description: In 2019, just three newly public companies did.   For Chesky, the gap between Airbnb’s debut share price of $68 and the $139/share it actually opened at translates to billions of dollars of missed opportunity (had the company initially sold its shares at that higher price). Plus, these first-day pops can make shares look soggy later.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Short Sellers on Pace for Worst Year Ever
item.description: Two of the most popular targets for short sellers, Moderna and Tesla, have gained 702% and 629% this year, respectively, wiping out short sellers’ March profits.   A quick refresher: Short sellers make money when a company loses value.   But it’s been nothing but pain ever since.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Corporations Across Sectors Prepare to Make and Distribute the Vaccine
item.description: Pfizer and Moderna are expected to generate $32 billion in Covid-19 vaccine sales in 2021, according to Wall Street forecasts. They’re confident that together they have the capacity to deliver both the life-saving shot and the Christmas sweater you sent your aunt.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Finance Bosses Look Beyond Wall Street to Florida
item.description: Yesterday, Ken Moelis, the chairman and CEO of New York investment bank Moelis & Co., told Bloomberg he wouldn't stop his employees from moving to Florida.   It’s not just finance… And it’s not just New York bleeding business leaders. And if that talent wants to do it in Florida, that’s where we’ll support them.”   Right on cue, software giant Oracle said yesterday it was moving its HQ from Redwood City, CA, to Austin, TX.   It’s not exactly a secret that Florida is warmer than New York, boasts a cheaper cost of living, and has world-class institutions like Publix.     Why now?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Short Sellers on Pace for Worst Year Ever
item.description: Two of the most popular targets for short sellers, Moderna and Tesla, have gained 702% and 629% this year, respectively, wiping out short sellers’ March profits.   A quick refresher: Short sellers make money when a company loses value.   But it’s been nothing but pain ever since.

item.title: The Popping IPO Market Could Be “Broken”
item.description: In 2019, just three newly public companies did.   For Chesky, the gap between Airbnb’s debut share price of $68 and the $139/share it actually opened at translates to billions of dollars of missed opportunity (had the company initially sold its shares at that higher price). Plus, these first-day pops can make shares look soggy later.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Sony Buys Crunchyroll, Consolidates the Big Business of Bringing Japanese Anime to Western Viewers
item.description: Netflix can appease the casual viewer by sprinkling shows and movies into its existing service, while Funimation x Crunchyroll can satisfy the straight-from-Japan needs of the truly anime-obsessed.   Crunchyroll gives Sony a Snorlax-sized foothold in anime  In 2019, Sony combined three anime streaming services under its roof—France’s Wakanim, Australia’s Madman Anime Group, and the U.S.' Funimation—into a joint venture between Sony Pictures Entertainment and Sony Music Entertainment’s subsidiary, Aniplex. On Wednesday, Sony-owned anime streaming service Funimation agreed to acquire anime streaming service Crunchyroll from AT&T for $1.2 billion. But getting anime from Japan to the U.S. has historically been a slow and painful process. Medium dive: Read this Quora answer on the history of anime production, this Reddit thread on financing, and “The Dark Side of Japan’s Anime Industry” by Eric Margolis. Crunchyroll will also be folded into this streaming giant, which could mean a complete merger or just an exchange of content. Here’s how it works: Most anime is a collaboration between a studio and a production committee. That rabid love raises the question of whether anime is better suited to an all-in-one streamer like Netflix or a standalone service like Crunchyroll. Once an anime gets made, distribution is quick and painless... Deep dive: Listen to Anime in America from Crunchyroll and read The Soul of Anime: Collaborative Creativity and Japan’s Media Success Story by Ian Condry. there’s room for both Sony and Netflix to be successful anime streamers if the genre’s appeal continues to grow beyond its most hardcore fans. Enter: streaming services Pay-per-month services are getting anime to Western fans in two ways: The Crunchyroll way: In 2006, Crunchyroll started as a quasi-legal YouTube channel for fan-subtitled anime, but evolved into an above-board streaming service in 2009. When Cartoon Network started Toonami (part of Adult Swim) in 1997, the co-creators looked beyond the U.S. for more adult cartoons at the turn of the millennia. Foreign: U.S. media companies didn’t think there would be demand for content that’s not from Hollywood. Both will achieve the same end goal: exporting Japanese anime to Western audiences. Sometimes, major studios like Kyoto Animation and Shaft are part of the production committees themselves, according to this highly detailed Reddit post.   Looking ahead... Adult Swim SVP Jason DeMarco wrote on Twitter that it’s “doubtful” any of the original shows Toonami and Crunchyroll are currently co-producing will be affected.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Hyundai Acquires Boston Dynamics and Its Robot Dogs for $1.1 Billion
item.description: Some of the sectors Boston Dynamics’s tech might help with one day: self-driving vehicles, smart factories, and healthcare.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Corporations Across Sectors Prepare to Make and Distribute the Vaccine
item.description: Moderna did just $60 million in revenue last year. Pfizer and Moderna are expected to generate $32 billion in Covid-19 vaccine sales in 2021, according to Wall Street forecasts.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Finance Bosses Look Beyond Wall Street to Florida
item.description: Yesterday, Ken Moelis, the chairman and CEO of New York investment bank Moelis & Co., told Bloomberg he wouldn't stop his employees from moving to Florida.   It’s not just finance… And it’s not just New York bleeding businesses. And if that talent wants to do it in Florida, that’s where we’ll support them.”   Right on cue, software giant Oracle said yesterday it was moving its HQ from Redwood City, CA, to Austin, TX.   It’s not exactly a secret that Florida is warmer than New York, boasts a cheaper cost of living, and has world-class institutions like Publix.     Why now?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: How to Host a Company Holiday Party During Covid?
item.description: But ordinary times these are not.   One benefit of an online holiday party?   You’ll find everything you need right here. What is Slack’s video function but an opportunity for embarrassment waiting to happen? We aren’t so sure. “At corporate holiday parties, you typically get a handful of folks who end up drinking too much and do something embarrassing,” Ryan Costello of Event Farm told the WSJ.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Jobless Claims, Food Insecurity Rise
item.description: Housing: A homebuying boom has added a collective $1 trillion in homeowner equity this year (an average of $17,000 per homeowner), according to CoreLogic. Applications from self-employed and gig workers for a federal program rose 48%, but that program expires Dec. 26.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Disney Announces Disney+ Content Slate
item.description: Zoom out: Disney’s streaming unit is growing rapidly, but still incurring big losses ($2.8 billion in fiscal year 2020) that analysts expect to peak in the next two years.   But Disney isn't planning to follow WarnerMedia down that path just yet. WarnerMedia is planning joint theater-HBO Max premieres next year.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: FDA Approves Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine, Raising Questions Over Who Counts as Essential
item.description: Now comes the hard part  Pfizer, BioNTech, and other manufacturers have generated lifesaving products at a breathtaking speed...   Bottom line: It will ultimately fall to the states to decide which workers are “essential” enough to receive the first, limited doses of the vaccine. Currently, the only clear directive is that healthcare workers and residents of long-term care facilities go first—and no industry reps dispute that.   Unblinding would hamstring the research process... but it would also get people vaccinated.
item.author: Eliza Carter
